Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 15th International Conference in Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED 2011)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks funding to support the travel of advanced doctoral students so that they can participate in the 15th International Conference in Artificial Intelligence in Education and in the Young Researchers Track (YRT) that is part of that conference. The Young Researchers Track provides a forum for Ph.D. students to present and discuss their work with mentors from outside of their home institutions and to meet peers with similar interests. Mentoring happens in two ways -- as part of the Young Researchers Track, where they will be encouraged and offered feedback by three mentors, and through an individual mentoring program where each doctoral student will be matched with a mentor with expertise in the student's research area. Mentors will be senior AI and ED researchers.

Participants in the Young Researchers Track are members of the next generation of cyberlearning researchers. Participation in the proposed program will supplement their education at their home institutions and help prepare them to be leaders in transforming education through the use of learning technologies.

• AIED Society and Conference
    The International AIED Society organizes a biennial AIED conference (see
    http://ijaied.org/conf/list/ ), which is the main forum for reporting the best international research in the field of AI in Education. The conferences provide the opportunity for the exchange of information and ideas on related research, development and applications. The AIED conferences are highly refereed international events and serve as reference guidelines for the research community. Acceptance rates for full paper presentations at the conference range from 25-30%.   Each paper is generally reviewed by three referees and the reviewing process is carefully overseen by Senior Program Committee members, who write an additional meta-review. The Program Chairs make the final accept/reject decisions.

The AIED Society, an international society of researchers that represent over 40 countries throughout the world, has a management structure in place for implementing the Doctoral Consortium and Young Researcher’s Track. The conference organization includes a Conference Chair (Judy Kay, University of Sydney for AIED 2011), Program Chairs (Gautam Biswas, Vanderbilt University and Susan Bull, University of Birmingham for AIED 2011), an Organizing Chair and Committee (see  ttp://www.aied2011.canterbury.ac.nz/committees), a Young Researcher’s Track Chair and Committee, Tutorial Chairs, Workshop Chairs, an Interactive Events Chair, a Publicity Chair, a Sponsorship Chair, over 50 members of a Senior Program Committee, and about 100 members of the program committee and 50 additional reviewers.  There is clearly a management structure in place and a large community of researchers to mentor the students selected for the doctoral consortium. The YRT/DC has been very successful in past conferences. Comments and feedback from previous AIED conferences indicate that the carefully structured conference format continues to be professionally rewarding and stimulating to all who attend. 

Participant Selection Process

Funded participants were selected from among the US-based participants of the Symposium, most of these participants were authors selected through peer review of research abstracts (three reviewers per abstract).  This grant paid full or partial travel reimbursements for 13 graduate students, who were selected from among the US-based participants at AIED 2011 to make presentations in the Young Researcher Track (YRT) or the main conference at AIED 2011. 

The selection process for the student travel awards was made through a special call for submissions to the YRT as part of the main conference. The call for submissions (see http://www.aied2011.canterbury.ac.nz/docs/yrt/aied2011-call-for-yrt-letter.pdf) required students to submit three page papers with references that included the following information:

  • The problem(s) that is addressed by the research and how it fits into the bigger picture
  • The aims and objectives of the research
  • The methodology to achieve the aims and objectives
  • The main contribution(s) of the research to the AIED community.

Students had to be pursuing their PhD studies in a recognized US university, and they were required to justify that their research was at a stage where feedback from the AIED community might be of value. In addition, students were required to submit a sponsoring letter from their research advisor.
